title.narrative: Defending and educating to build a culture of peace

description.narrative:
Several sentences against the Salvadoran State for serious human rights violations have ordered justice and reparation for the victims. Also, the General Amnesty Law was declarated unconstitutional. It´s allowed to reopen the cases of El Mozote Massacre, El Sumpul Massacre and the Magnicide against Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero. According with the observatory on violence and insecurity against youth, only in the first half of 2017, in average, 9 people were killed daily. In 269 cases the victims have been children, in addition to 2,144 complaints of sexual abuse and 705 denounces of disappeared children. The government strategy on security policies is aimed to criminalise vulnerable groups and repress people in "maximum security prisons", ignoring all the international human rights committments. This situation has worsened over the years. Human rights organisations in El Salvador have denounced it before international bodies such as the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR).
During the previous project supported by CAFOD, Tutela Legal - María Julia Hernández identified psychosocial needs in young people who live in communities affected by armed conflict. Many of them showed lack of emotional support and live under pressure to belong to gangs, added to risks of police harassment or adictions. This process has allowed to share information and create a young human rights defenders network.
The current project is aimed to strenghten this work as a long-term process in the municipalities of Apopa, Tonacatepeque and Quezaltepeque. Likewise, legal advisory and accompaniment in cases of human rights violations will provide free support to the Salvadoran people in obtaining truth and justice in their cases.
